title: Judgment on Samaria and Judah
shortSummary: Micah 1 pronounces God's coming judgment on the northern kingdom of Israel (Samaria) and the southern kingdom of Judah for their sins and idolatry. The chapter vividly describes the Lord’s righteous anger and the resulting devastation, calling the people to hear and repent. It sets the tone for Micah’s prophetic ministry during the reigns of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.
timeline: c. 750-700 BC - Reigns of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Micah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet from Moresheth who delivers God's message of judgment against Israel and Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Jotham
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah during whose reign Micah began prophesying.

keyCharacters.name: Ahaz
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah known for idolatry and political alliances, reigning during Micah’s ministry.

keyCharacters.name: Hezekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah noted for religious reform, reigning during the latter part of Micah’s prophetic activity.

definitions.definition: A native of Moresheth, a town in Judah; identifying Micah’s hometown.
Elevated sites used for idol worship, often associated with pagan practices condemned by the prophets.
Carved idols or statues worshiped as gods, forbidden by the Ten Commandments.
Expressions of deep mourning and lamentation, often used in prophetic literature to depict sorrow over judgment.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Hear
outline.description: Micah introduces himself and calls all the earth to listen as God’s judgment is about to be revealed, establishing the authority of the message.

outline.heading: The Lord’s Coming Judgment
outline.description: God is depicted as coming forth in power to judge the earth, with imagery of mountains melting and valleys splitting, emphasizing His sovereign wrath.

outline.heading: Reason for Judgment: Sin of Israel and Judah
outline.description: The transgressions of Jacob (Israel) and the sins of Judah are identified as the cause of judgment, including idolatry and corruption.

outline.heading: The Lament over the Coming Destruction
outline.description: Micah expresses deep sorrow and mourning for the devastation coming upon various cities of Judah, highlighting the certainty and severity of God’s punishment.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and its consequences, prompting sincere repentance and turning back to God.
Trust in God’s righteous judgment while also embracing His mercy through obedience and faithfulness.
Respond to God’s warnings with heartfelt sorrow and a commitment to reject idolatry in all forms.
Encourage prayerful intercession for communities and leaders to seek God’s guidance and deliverance.

keyVerses.text: Hear, all ye people; hearken, O earth, and all that therein is: and let the Lord GOD be witness against you, the Lord from his holy temple.
keyVerses.significance: This verse calls universal attention to God’s impending judgment, emphasizing His holiness and authority.

keyVerses.text: For, behold, the LORD cometh forth out of his place, and will come down, and tread upon the high places of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the active and powerful intervention of God against sin, especially idolatry symbolized by the high places.

keyVerses.text: For the transgression of Jacob is all this, and for the sins of the house of Israel. What is the transgression of Jacob? is it not Samaria? and what are the high places of Judah? are they not Jerusalem?
keyVerses.significance: This verse identifies the root cause of judgment—sin and idolatry in both Israel and Judah—making the message directly relevant to the people.

keyVerses.text: Therefore I will wail and howl, I will go stripped and naked: I will make a wailing like the dragons, and mourning as the owls.
keyVerses.significance: Micah’s personal lament models the appropriate response to God’s judgment and the sorrow over the nation’s sin.
